text:
At least 10 people were killed 
in a Russian missile strike on an
apartment building in southern Ukraine overnight.

And former President Donald Trump is expected 
to appear in a federal court in Miami today.

Good morning, I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

A Russian missile slammed into an apartment 
building in southern Ukraine before dawn today,

killing at least 10 people and wounding about 
two dozen others. NPR's Greg Myre reports this

is the latest in a long series of Russian 
attacks that have hit civilian targets:

"The missile strike caused deaths, injuries and 
massive damage to the five-story apartment block

as residents were sleeping. The building 
was still smoldering after sunrise in the

southern city of Kryvyi Rih. Russia continues 
to fire missiles and drones into Ukraine almost

every night. Ukraine's Air Force said it shot 
down 11 of the 14 incoming Russian missiles,

but two managed to hit Kryvyi Rih. The city 
was already reeling from the destruction

of a major dam last week — the city 
was getting 70% of its water from a

reservoir created by the dam. Officials say 
the city now faces severe water shortages.
"Greg Myre, NPR News, Kyiv."

Former President and 2024 Republican 
presidential candidate Donald Trump

is now in southern Florida. NPR's 
Franco Ordoñez reports he's getting

ready for his first appearance 
in a federal courtroom in Miami:

"The former president faces unprecedented criminal 
charges over his handling of classified materials,

but those close to his campaign say he will not 
give an inch. Former aides like Brian Lanza,

who remains in very close contact with the 
campaign, acknowledge it's a challenge,

but he says the former president and his team also 
see this as an opportunity to rally support around

a key campaign message — that there is a double 
standard of treatment at the Justice Department:

'That there's a dual track of judicial system 
in the United States that appears to be,

you know, thumb on a scale towards 
conservatives and benefiting liberals.'

"The campaign is already fundraising 
on the effort, and Trump's expected

to publicly address the indictment 
several hours after appearing in court.
"Franco Ordoñez, NPR News."

House Speaker Kevin McCarthy appears to have 
resolved a dispute with a small group of very

conservative lawmakers. They were angry over 
his agreement with President Biden to lift

the debt ceiling. The lawmakers had blocked 
all House floor action for a couple of days

last week. They even blocked bills that had 
Republican support. McCarthy is acknowledging

that he could face future obstacles from 
extremely conservative House members.

Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker has signed a 
bill that outlaws book bans in his state.

He says efforts to silence writers have 
been focused on marginalized communities,

including LGBTQ Americans and authors 
who write about Black history:

"Illinois' young people shouldn't be kept from 
learning about the realities of the world.

I want them to become critical thinkers 
exposed to ideas that they disagree with,

proud of what our nation has overcome, 
and thoughtful about what comes next."

The law will withhold grant funding from Illinois 
libraries that pull books from their shelves.
This is NPR.
